School of Resource and Environmental Sciences Wuhan University Wuhan Hubei 430079 PR China Different transition metals were used to modify commercial V2O5-WO3-TiO2 catalysts to remove slip ammonia and residual NOx from the tail of SCR system. The performance of selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 (NH3-SCO) and selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3 (NH3-SCR) of different catalysts at 150-400 ℃ was studied. The results showed that the loading of transition metals could significantly improve the NH3 oxidation ability of the catalysts, and the presence of NO furtherly promoted it. Cu-SCR catalyst obtained the best activity of both NH3 oxidation and NOx reduction at 350 ℃, and had excellent SO2 and H2O resistance in the presence of NO. The characterization results indicated that the transition metals enhanced the amounts of acid sites and redox ability of the catalysts. Moreover, the transition metals could increase the active oxygen and improve the catalytic performance of the catalysts by the redox reaction with V4+/V5+. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Simultaneous removal of slip ammonia and residual NOx in SCR system and the reaction mechanism of Cu-SCR Keywords Transition metals Slip ammonia Selective catalytic reduction of NO Selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 1 Introduction The General Office of the State Council of the People's Republic of China put forward the concept of ultra-low emission of coal-fired power plants for the first time in 2014 [1] and nitrogen oxide (NOx) has been one of the main air pollutants of coal-fired power plants. According to the “Coal Energy Conservation and Emission Reduction Action Plan (2014-2020)”, the discharge amount of NOx is required to be less than 50 mg/Nm3 [2], while ultra-low-emission makes more stringent requirements for the denitrification technology of coal-fired power plants. At present, NH3-SCR technology is widely used in the removal of NOx in industry by using V2O5-WO3-TiO2 catalyst [3,4], which can convert NOx into harmless N2 and H2O in the presence of NH3 [5]. The theoretical denitrification efficiency of NH3-SCR can reach more than 90% [6]. However, due to the deactivation of the catalysts and uneven gas mixing, the denitrification efficiency of SCR cannot live up to the theoretical expectation under the real plant regulation, and there is still residual NOx in the system [7]. Therefore, in order to improve the denitrification efficiency and satisfy the ultra-low-emission standard, coal-fired power plants usually reduce NOx by injecting excessive NH3, which not only improves the NOx removal efficiency, but also causes ammonia escape [8,9]. To be specific, ammonia escape phenomenon refers to the process that the excess part of ammonia after reacting with nitrogen oxides flows to desulfurization tower, dust collector and finally discharged from chimney with flue gas [10]. The hazards of ammonia escape include the following sides: (1) As a toxic gas, ammonia is the main pollutant involved in the formation of atmospheric aerosols, causing acidification of soil and eutrophication of water, which causes serve secondary environmental pollution;(2) SCR catalyst can oxidize SO2 in the flue gas to form SO3, which can easily react with slip ammonia in SCR to create ammonium bisulfate, which is viscous and prone to adhere to fly ash in flue gas, leading to corrosion and blockage of catalytic bed and air preheater; (3) Ammonia escape can also corrode the catalyst module, resulting in catalyst deactivation and blockage, which causes significant reduction of the life of the catalyst [11-13]. Therefore, how to solve the problem of ammonia escape has been an urgent task under the background of ultra-low-emission. At present, the major countermeasures for ammonia escape in coal-fired power plants are controlling ammonia escape by optimizing the accuracy of ammonia injection control system or improving the mixing uniformity of NH3 and NOx at the inlet [8]. However, the primary problems of these methods are the difficult operation, low treatment efficiency and the limitation in realization, which are obviously disadvantageous to the large-scale and efficient treatment of ammonia escape. What's more, the researches have shown that there are several methods for the treatment of waste NH3, including absorption, catalytic decomposition, biofiltration [14-17], etc. However, these methods have the problems of high investment cost, difficult operation, low ammonia treatment efficiency or secondary pollution, which limit their wide application in coal-fired power plants. In contrast, selective catalytic oxidation (NH3-SCO) has attracted much attention due to its advantages of low energy consumption, stable system, high ammonia treatment efficiency and less secondary pollution. In this process, NH3 is oxidized to harmless N2 and H2O through the catalyst [18,19]. According to the previous researches, the most active and wide-used catalysts were precious metal catalysts and transition metal catalysts. Precious metal catalysts included Pt, Pd, Ru, Ir, Au and Ag, while metal oxides (Al2O3,SiO2,TiO2) and molecular sieves (ZSM) were used as supports [20,21]. The catalysts obtained excellent NH3 oxidation performance. The experiment showed that Ag-TiO2 [22], Ag-Al2O3 [23], Pt-Al2O3 [24], Pt-ZSM-5 [25] catalysts could reach more than 90% in terms of NH3 oxidation efficiency. However, there are some problems of high price and poor N2 selectivity for those precious metal catalysts. By comparison, transition metals are abundant and low in price, and oxides such as Cu, Fe, Mn, Co are considered as cheap substitutes for precious metal catalysts because of their good oxidation ability. Cu-TiO2 [26], Cu-Al2O3 [27], Cu-ZSM-5 [28], Fe-Al2O3 [29] and other catalysts are observed to show significant NH3 oxidation efficiency over 90% in suitable conditions, while their N2 selectivity was relatively high at more than 80%. However, at present, the vast majority of researches use Al2O3 or ZSM as the catalyst carrier, which is different from commercial SCR catalyst. It has been found that TiO2 modified with V obtains a certain catalytic activity for NH3 [30], and the main active component of SCR catalyst is V2O5. Therefore, adding transition metals as active components to improve the ammonia oxidation ability of commercial SCR catalysts is promising in eliminating ammonia escape. At the same time, if the modified catalyst has higher catalytic capacity of NH3-SCR, it can control both the slip ammonia and the residual NOx at the tail of SCR system, which is advantageous to improve the NOx removal efficiency of the system. Therefore, in this study, a series of transition metals (Cu, Fe, Mn, Co) modified commercial SCR catalysts by improved impregnation method, and their NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR performance were studied. Characterization experiments BET, XRD, TEM, XPS, NH3-TPD and H2-TPR were used to observe the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts. The valence, surface acidic sites and redox properties of the transition metals supported on the catalysts were studied as well. This research has guiding significance in the treatment of escaping NH3 and residual NOx in SCR denitrification system. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The commercial SCR catalyst used in this study contains 1.2%V2O5, 5.0%WO3 and TiO2 supported. An improved impregnation method was used to prepare the modified catalysts [31]. First, the SCR catalyst was ground into powder and the nitrates of the different metals (Cu, Fe, Mn, Co) were dissolved in deionized water, and a certain amount of SCR catalyst was put into the solution to provide a mass ratio of 1:99 for metals and SCR catalyst. The amounts of Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, Fe(NO3)3•9H2O, Mn(NO3)2(50wt%aq.) and Co(NO3)2•6H2O were 0.38g,0.72g,0.64g,0.49g, respectively. After magnetically stirring for 2 h at 60°C, the solution was dried at 105°C for 15h. Then the obtained samples were transferred to the muffle furnace and calcined at 400°C in air for 4 h. At last, the prepared catalysts were ground to less than 40 mesh for studies. 2.2 Activity measurement The NH3 oxidation and NOx reduction performance of the catalysts prepared in this experiment were tested at 150-400 ℃. The experimental device consisted of a small simulated fixed-bed reaction system. The feed gas contained NH3, NO, SO2, H2O and O2 with N2 as the carrier. The gas flow was adjusted by mass flow controllers, and then fully mixed into the reaction device to control the total gas flow at 1 L / min. The water vapor was produced by heating the blister. 0.5g catalyst was placed in a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 10mm by quartz cotton loading and quartz sand covering. The quartz tube was embedded in a high temperature tubular furnace, and the reaction temperature of the catalysts was adjusted by the temperature control program. The NOx concentration in the outlet flue gas was detected by the flue gas analyzer (Ecom-J2KN, Germany), while the NH3 concentration was determined by Nessler's reagent spectrophotometry. SO2 and other acidic gases produced in the experiment were absorbed by NaOH solution. The removal efficiency of NH3 and NOx was calculated by Eq. (1) and Eq. (2), and the N2 selectivity of the catalysts was calculated by Eq. (3) and Eq. (4), and N2 selectivitya and N2 selectivityb respectively represented the percentage of N2 when NO was absent and present in the inlet flue gas [32]. (1) N H 3 removal efficiency = [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n × 100 % (2) NO removal efficiency = [ 1 − [ N O ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t [ N O ] i n ] × 100 % (3) N 2 selectivit y a a = [ 1 − [ N O ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t ] × 100 % (4) N 2 selectivityb = [ 1 − [ N O 2 ] o u t + 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N H 3 ] o u t − [ N O ] o u t ] × 100 % 2.3 Catalysts characterization The specific surface area, pore volume, pore size and other parameters of the catalysts were tested by ASAP 2020 automatic rapid specific surface area and porosity analyzer produced by Micromeritics (Shanghai). The samples were dried and vacuum degassed to remove water and other impurities, and then tested at - 196 ℃ in liquid nitrogen atmosphere. The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The parameters of pore size and volume were obtained by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The crystal structure and other information of the catalysts were detected by D/MX-IIA X-ray diffractometer (XRD) produced by Rigaku company of Japan. The test conditions were Ka radiation of copper target and the scanning range was 20-80 °. XRD data were analyzed by Jade. The microstructure of the catalysts was studied by JEM-2100 field emission transmission electron microscope (TEM). ESCALAB 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the chemical composition and valence of the catalysts. The radioactive source was Al Ka (hv = 1486.6ev). The energy value of C1s bond was 284.6ev to correct the final test data. XPS data was analyzed by XPS PEAK. The acid sites of the catalysts were detected by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). First, 200 mg sample was pretreated at 300℃ of He gas flow for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature and adsorbed NH3 to saturation, and then treated with He for 30 min more. The catalysts that already adsorbed NH3 were heated from the room temperature to 600°C with a temperature ramp of 10°C/min. The desorption of NH3 was detected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was used to test the redox performance of the catalysts. The instrument used was AutoChem II 2920 automatic chemical adsorption instrument produced by Micromeritics company of the United States. First, about 0.05 g of the sample pretreated for 2 hours in N2 gas flow at 300℃, then cooled to 50 ℃ in the same atmosphere. The experiment of H2-TPR was carried out in 1% H2-He gas flow. The gas flow rate was 50ml/min and the heating rate was 10 ℃/min, rising from 50℃to 950 ℃. The consumption of H2 was detected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3 oxidation performance In order to effectively remove the slip ammonia from SCR denitrification system, the NH3 oxidation performance of M-SCR and SCR catalysts was studied. Fig. 1 (a) shows the ammonia catalytic performance of different catalysts with different temperature. The compositions of flue gas were N2, 50 ppm NH3 and 4% O2, and the reaction temperature was 150 ℃–400°C. It can be seen from Fig. 1 that the loading of transition metals on SCR catalyst could significantly improve the oxidation efficiency of NH3, and higher temperature was more conducive to the oxidation of NH3. At 150 ℃, the NH3 oxidation efficiency of all catalysts was less than 15% and with the increase of the temperature to 350 ℃, the NH3 removal efficiency of SCR catalyst had no obvious change, which was still less than 20%. However, the removal efficiency of SCR catalyst loaded with transition metals increased dramatically. At 350℃, the NH3 oxidation efficiency of Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR and Co-SCR reached 88%, 87%, 83% and 76% respectively. With the temperature rising to 400 ℃, the removal efficiency of the catalyst increased slightly and Cu-SCR was the most efficient of these catalysts, reaching 91%. After the later characterization, it showed that the abundant acidic sites and excellent redox ability could contribute to the significant efficiency of Cu-SCR catalyst. The oxidation products of NH3-SCO not only produced harmless N2, but also created harmful N2O, NO and NO2, causing serve secondary pollution [33]. Therefore, an ideal catalyst is expected to have high N2 selectivity. Fig.1(b) shows the N2 selectivity of different SCR catalysts at different temperature. In contrast to NH3 oxidation, N2 selectivity decreased as the temperature rose. The N2 selectivity of all catalysts was higher than 97% at 150 ℃. As the temperature increased to 350 ℃, the N2 selectivity of SCR catalyst was the highest among all catalysts due to its poor oxidation ability of NH3, reaching 97%. The N2 selectivity of Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR and Co-SCR decreased to 89%, 87%, 75% and 69% respectively. When the temperature increased to 400 ℃, the N2 selectivity decreased to 84%, 83%, 71% and 54% respectively, which still showed a significant decline. In addition, as shown in Fig.S1, the amount of N2O as the by-product rose with the increase of temperature. The amount of N2O of Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR and Co-SCR at 350℃ was 2.9ppm,3ppm,5.9ppm,6.8ppm,0.2ppm respectively, indicating that the introduced transition metals contributed to the formation of N2O as well as the decrease of N2 selectivity. In general, all M-SCR catalysts showed excellent NH3 oxidation ability at 350 ℃, and Cu-SCR had the best performance. Considering both NH3 oxidation efficiency and N2 selectivity, Cu-SCR catalyst was the best choice for NH3-SCO reaction and 350 ℃ was the most suitable temperature in the absence of NO. 3.2 NH3 oxidation and SCR performance in the presence of NO The ratio of NH3 / NO is one of the important factors affecting the actual denitrification efficiency of SCR system. In order to effectively remove NOx in coal-fired flue gas, the ratio of NH3 / NO in SCR system is usually set at 0.8-1.2 [34,35]. Whereas, insufficient NH3 results in incomplete SCR reaction and reduce the denitrification efficiency, while excessive NH3 leads to ammonia slip and cause secondary pollution. In fact, due to the deactivation of SCR catalyst and inadequate gas mixing, SCR system cannot remove all NOx even if there is enough NH3 [36-38] and there is still a small amount of NOx in the tail of SCR system. Therefore, the effect of SCR performance and residual NOx on the NH3 oxidation performance of the prepared SCR catalyst was studied by taking NH3 / NO ratio of 1:1 as an example. As shown in Fig.2(a), after adding 50ppm NO, the NH3 oxidation efficiency of all catalysts at different temperatures was significantly enhanced and with the increase of temperature, the oxidation efficiency of NH3 also increased dramatically. At 350 ℃, the NH3 oxidation efficiencies of Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR, CO-SCR and SCR catalysts reached 95%, 94%, 92%, 86% and 78% respectively, which indicated that the NH3 oxidation efficiency of the catalysts could be significantly improved by loading transition metals. When the temperature furtherly increased to 400 ℃, the efficiency of the catalyst changed slightly, and the NH3 oxidation efficiency of Cu-SCR reached 97%. These results indicated that the addition of NO considerably promoted the oxidation of NH3. The NO removal efficiency at 150-400 ℃ was shown in Fig.2(b). It can be seen that at 150-350 ℃, the denitrification performance of all catalysts enhanced significantly with the increase of temperature, and when the temperature continued to rise to 400 ℃, the NO removal efficiency declined, indicating that too high temperature was not beneficial to SCR reaction. The reason could be that the increase of NH3 oxidation reaction efficiency with the rise of temperature led to the low concentration of NH3 involved in NO reduction and the decrease of NO removal efficiency. At 350 ℃, the NO removal efficiencies of Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR, Co-SCR and SCR catalysts reached 94%, 93%, 94%, 90% and 90% respectively, indicating that the loading of transition metals could improve the NOx removal efficiency of the catalysts. At 150-300 ℃, the denitrification efficiency of the catalyst was higher than the ammonia removal efficiency, which indicated that the reaction ratio of NH3 and NO was not strictly 1:1, or because the catalysts had NH3 storage and release capacity and the NH3 adsorbed and stored on the catalyst surface could participate in the reduction of NO [39,40]. It was similar to the phenomenon observed in the absence of NO that N2 selectivity decreased with raising temperature, but the rate was much lower than that in the absence of NO in Fig. 2 (c). At 350 ℃, the N2 selectivity of Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR, Co-SCR and SCR catalysts was all above 90%, which were 96%, 95%, 92%, 91% and 98% respectively and all of them were higher than those obtained without NO, indicating that the presence of no could facilitate SCR reaction, reduce the formation of by-products and improve the selectivity of N2. In addition, in the presence of NO, the amount of N2O of all catalysts was negligible, which was no more than 4ppm (Fig.S2). As stated above, the NH3 oxidation efficiency and N2 selectivity of all catalysts in the presence of NO were higher than those in the absence of NO, and Cu-SCR catalyst had the highest NH3 oxidation efficiency. On the other hand, in the presence of NO, Cu-SCR showed more excellent SCR reaction efficiency than other catalysts, indicating that Cu-SCR could effectively oxidize slip ammonia as well as remove residual NOx. Moreover, Cu-SCR had higher N2 selectivity than other SCR catalysts modified with transition metals. Therefore, in order to deal with the residual NOx and slip NH3 simultaneously, the Cu-SCR catalyst was the most ideal one among all the SCR catalysts modified with transition metals. 3.3 Effects of SO2 and H2O SO2 and H2O are both important components in coal-fired flue gas, so the influence of them on the catalytic performance of Cu-SCR was studied, as shown in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that in the absence of NO, the addition of 500 ppm SO2 made the ammonia removal efficiency of the catalyst decrease significantly, from 88% to 56%, while in the presence of NO, the toxicity of SO2 on the catalyst dropped rapidly and the ammonia removal efficiency only declined from 95% to 87%. In addition, the denitrification efficiency still reached 90%, indicating that the presence of NO enhanced the sulfur tolerance of ammonia oxidation reaction of Cu-SCR. The reason might be that sulfate could occupy part of the active oxygen sites on the catalyst surface, resulting in inhibiting the oxidation of intermediate product NH2 and the reaction was NH2 + O2 → NOx, and the added NO could directly react with NH2 as well as reduce the effect of SO2 [41,42]. What's more, SO2 could improve the N2 selectivity of the catalyst by 2% and the rise came to 3% with the presence of NO. This might be due to the decrease of oxidation ability of the catalyst or the increase of acid sites on the surface of the catalyst as a result of the addition of SO2 [43]. Similarly, no matter whether there was NO or not, H2O had a slight inhibition on the removal of NH3 and NOx, while N2 selectivity showed a slight increase. In the absence of NO, the oxidation efficiency of NH3 decreased from 88% to 81%. When the ratio of NH3/ NO was 1:1, the removal efficiency of NH3 and NO declined by 5% and 4%, respectively. This might result from the adsorption of H2O on the surface of TiO2, as the formation of water layer would reduce the surface acidic sites and then inhibit NH3 adsorption [44]. H2O also promoted the N2 selectivity by 2%. In addition, when SO2 and H2O exist in the gas at the same time, the catalytic performance of the catalysts decreased more significantly than that when there was only SO2 or H2O. What's more, the amount of N2O decreased to 2.1ppm and 0.9ppm respectively in the absence and presence of NO with the significant decline in the catalytic performance of Cu-SCR (Fig.S3). 3.4 BET The specific surface area, pore volume and pore size of SCR catalysts modified by different transition metals are shown in the Table 1 . It can be seen that the specific surface area of SCR catalyst was the largest at 76.4 m²/g. The atomic numbers of Cu, Fe, Mn and Co are close to each other, and the atomic weight and ion size of them are similar, so the specific surface areas of the modified catalysts were very similar at around 74 m²/g, which were lower than the SCR catalyst. At the same time, the modification of transition metal also caused the slight decrease of pore volume and average pore size. It indicated that the transition metal destroyed the pore structure of the catalyst and blocked the internal pores [45,46]. However, these catalysts had similar specific surface areas and pore size parameters but their SCO activity was obviously different, indicating that these physical properties were not the main reason for the SCO activity of the catalysts. 3.5 XRD and TEM XRD patterns of the catalysts were recorded to study the crystal structure of catalysts. It can be seen that only the diffraction peaks of anatase TiO2 were observed at 25.3°, 37.8°, 48.0°, 53.9°, 55.1° in the catalyst before and after modification (PDF21-1272) [47,48]. The transition metals did not change the intensity of TiO2 characteristic diffraction peak significantly. For all catalysts, there was no obvious characteristic diffraction peak of transition metals (Fe, Cu, Mn, Co), V species and W species, which indicated that the V species, W species and the introduced transition metals were amorphous dispersed on the TiO2 surface or the particle sizes of them were smaller than the detection limit of XRD (0.3nm) and could not be detected [49,50]. The morphology of SCR and Cu-SCR catalyst observed by TEM were shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen from the figure that low Cu loading (1%) had no obvious effect on SCR catalyst. The catalysts were both in circular structure and showed no apparent change in size. What's more, there was no obvious grain structure appeared on the surface of the catalyst, indicating that Cu species was highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst, which is consistent with the results of XRD. 3.6 XPS XPS was used to study the surface components and the chemical states of elements. The surface atomic concentration was summarized in the Table 2 based on the XPS results. It can be seen that the ratios of transition metals to vanadium were close, but their SCO performance was significantly different. The results of O 1s bands of different catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 (b), and they were fitted by XPS peak. The low energy sub-band at 529.9ev belonged to lattice oxygen O2−(denoted as Oβ), and the high energy sub-band at 530.5ev belonged to surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα), such as O2 2− or O− from defect oxides [51,52]. The relative concentration ratios of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) of different catalysts are summarised in Table. It can be seen that the transition metal caused the increase of the ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ), while Cu-SCR catalyst had the highest ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ). Compared with lattice oxygen Oβ, surface adsorped of oxygen Oα has been observed to have better oxidability and mobility [53], so it was more active in NH3-SCO reaction and more beneficial for the oxidation of NH3. Therefore, more Oα on the transition metal modified catalysts was one of the reasons for promoting the efficiency of SCO, and Cu-SCR with the highest proportion of Oα had the highest NH3 oxidation rate.The XPS results of V 2p and Ti 2p are shown in Fig.6(c) and Fig.6(a). The binding energy of Ti 2p3/2 was 458.9eV, indicating that the titanium species mainly existed in the form of Ti4+. As the results of V 2p3/2, the peak at 517.3eV belonged to V5+, while that at 516.3eV belonged to V4+. The relative concentration ratios of V5+/ V4+of different catalysts are summarised in Table. It can be seen that the transition metal caused the increase of the ratio of V5+/ V4+, while Cu-SCR catalyst had the highest ratio of V5+/ V4+. The XPS results of different transition metals are shown in Fig.6(d). Each transition metal were observed to have more than one valence state, which indicated that they had complex coordination spheres when forming metal oxides or vanadates. The XPS results of Cu 2p3/2 included two peaks, the peak at 932.1eV belonged to Cu+ or Cu0, while that at 932.9eV belonged to Cu2+. The peaks of Fe 2p3/2 could be observed at 711.1ev and 712.9ev, which were presented as Fe2+ and Fe3+. For Mn and Co species, the main forms Mn2+,Mn3+,Mn4+,Co2+,Co3+ were observed. Combined with the concentration changes of Oα and V5+ on the catalyst surface, it can be speculated that redox reactions occurred on the catalyst surface [54], such as Cu2++V4+⇋Cu++V5+, Fe3++V4+⇋Fe2++V5+, Mn4++V4+⇋Mn3++V5+, Mn3++V4+⇋Mn2++V5+, Co3++V4+⇋Co2++V5+. The existence of these reactions resulted in the formation of electron holes and unsaturated chemical bonds on the surface of the modified catalysts, which significantly increased the content of surface absorbed oxygen Oα on the catalyst surface [55,56], contributing to the improvement of the catalytic activity of the catalysts. 3.7 NH3-TPD NH3-TPD was used to study the adsorption of NH3 on the active sites of catalyst surface. It can be seen from Fig. 7 (a) that the images of all catalysts mainly showed two peaks. The peaks at 130 ℃ and 131 ℃ were attributed to the NH3 and NH3 species absorbed on weak acid sites [57-61]. Except for the Fe-SCR, the peaks of Cu-SCR, Mn-SCR and Co-SCR showed slightly weaker than the SCR catalyst. This might be due to the loading of transition metals covered some of the acidic sites on the catalyst surface [57-61]. In addition, the second peak could be observed at 394 ℃ for Cu-SCR, 438 ℃ for Fe-SCR, 450 ℃ for Mn-SCR, 428 ℃ for Co-SCR and 427 ℃ for SCR, which corresponded to the NH3 and NH3 species absorbed on strong acid sites [57-61]. NH3 adsorbed on strong acidic sites might tend to participate in the reaction of NH3, which was conducive to the oxidation of NH3. Compared with SCR catalyst, the loading of transition metals increased the intensity of these peaks, indicating that the adsorption capacity of NH3 was enhanced. Except for Cu-SCR, the temperature of strong acidic sites of the catalysts increased with the loading of transition metals, which represented the enhancement of acidity. The ratios of strong acid sites to weak acid sites for different catalysts are summarized in Figure. 7(b), while the total amounts of surface acid sites are summarized in Figure. 7(c). The proportion of strong acid sites to weak acid sites were 0.85,1.32,1.09.1.28,0.88 for SCR, Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR, Co-SCR catalyst, respectively. And the total surface acid sites of Cu-SCR, Fe-SCR, Mn-SCR, Co-SCR were 1.3,1.28,1.18,1.08 times of that of SCR catalyst. These results showed that the amounts of strong acid sites and acid sites on the surface of the catalyst significantly increased, especially for Cu-SCR, which could be one of the reasons for the increase of NH3 oxidation efficiency. 3.8 H2-TPR H2-TPR was used to reveal the redox performance of the catalysts, and the results were shown in Fig. 8 . For all catalysts, a peak was observed at high temperature (788 ℃-850 ℃) in the TPR profile, which was attributed to the reduction of V4+ to V3+ in SCR catalyst [59,61]. Compared with the raw SCR catalyst, the reduction temperature of V species decreased and the peak area increased with the loading of transition metals. In the medium and low temperature region, a peak could be observed at 469 ℃ for SCR catalyst, which was due to the reduction of V5+ to V4+ [62,63]. There were three peaks at 286 ℃, 328 ℃ and 432 ℃ in the figure for Cu-SCR catalyst. The peaks at 286 ℃ and 328 ℃ was assigned to the reduction of Cu+ and Cu2+ respectively [59], while the peak at 432 ℃ could be attributed to the reduction of the highly dispersed V species. After being modified with Fe, two peaks were observed at 427 ℃ and 467 ℃, representing the reduction of Fe2+ and Fe3+ respectively. For Mn-SCR and Co-SCR, only one peak could be observed at the medium and low temperature region, which was ascribed to the reduction of Mn4+ and Co3+ respectively. It can be seen that the loading of transition metals contributed to the significant rise of the peak area of the catalysts at the medium and low temperature region, and the reduction temperature of the catalysts decreased except for Mn-SCR, while Cu-SCR obtained the largest peak area and the lowest reduction temperature among all the catalysts. The results showed that the loading of transition metals was beneficial to improve the redox ability of SCR catalyst, and Cu-SCR catalyst had the best redox ability, which was beneficial to the improvement of NH3 oxidation ability and SCR reaction activity. It could be one of the reasons why Cu-SCR catalyst had the best catalytic performance in the activity measurement. Furthermore, combined with the catalytic performance of Cu-, Fe- and Mn-doped catalysts and the results of TPR and TPD, all of these catalysts obtained excellent redox and acid properties compared with SCR catalyst, which could fundamentally satisfy the requirements of NH3 and NO removal and kept their removal efficiency at a relatively high level, so it was hard to continue to furtherly improve the catalytic performance significantly. Therefore, the differences in redox and acid properties cannot be well reflected on the activity measurement as all of the catalysts showed excellent catalytic performance. 3.9 The reaction mechanism The NH3-SCO reaction mechanism of Cu-SCR was analyzed based on previous studies and the results of this experiment. In recent years, large amounts of researches have shown that the NH3-SCO reaction follows the i-SCR mechanism that NH3 is first oxidized by O2 to NOx, and NOx continues to oxidize NH3 to N2 [30,64]. Consequently, the NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR reaction mechanism of Cu-SCR catalyst was proposed in Fig. 9 : To begin with, NH3 was first adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst and activated to NH2*, then oxidized to NO3(ad) and NO2*(ad)by O2. NOx(ad)finally reacted with NH2* to form harmless N2 and H2O. NO(g) in the flue gas would directly react with NH2* or transform into NOx(ad)by O* and then consumed by NH2*, which was an important step in SCR reaction [42,59,65,66]. It indicated that NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR could simultaneously take place over Cu-SCR catalyst and the presence of NO was beneficial to the oxidation of NH3, which was consistent with the results in the activity measurement that NO significantly improved the removal efficiency of NH3. According to the results of NH3-TPD, the loading of Cu on SCR catalyst dramatically increased the amounts of acidic sites, which was conducive to the adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst surface. What's more, XPS results showed that Cu supported on SCR catalyst surface could create redox reaction Cu2++V4+⇋Cu++V5+, which provided a large number of electron holes and unsaturated chemical bonds. It could dramatically enhance the amount of the active oxygen on the catalyst surface and realize the efficient oxidation of NH3. Moreover. it was also advantageous to the oxidation of NO and then the oxidic products were consumed by NH2*, which contributed to the increase of the efficiency of NH3-SCR. 4 Conclusions Different transition metals (Cu, Fe, Mn, Co) were successfully used to modify commercial catalysts, and their NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR performances were studied. The results showed that all the M-SCR catalysts had excellent NH3 oxidation ability at 350 ℃, but the N2 selectivity decreased. At the same time, in the presence of NO, the catalysts obtained significant SCR activity, and the NH3 removal efficiency was furtherly enhanced. Among these catalysts, Cu-SCR was the one with the best SCO and SCR activity at 350 ℃, and it also showed good resistance to SO2 and H2O in the presence of NO. The characterization results showed that the transition metals on the catalysts were highly dispersed. And the reasons for the better catalytic performance of M-SCR catalysts could be that they obtained more and stronger acidic sites and better redox performance. Moreover, the transition metals on the surface of the catalysts could react with V4+/V5+, which increased the amount of active oxygen on the surface of the catalysts and enhanced the activity of them. Among all the catalyst modified with different transition metals, Cu-SCR catalyst showed the best characterization results and it was consistent with the active performance test, which indicated that Cu-SCR catalyst might be a potential catalyst in controlling slip ammonia and residual NOx at the tail of SCR system. coredata.dc:description: Different transition metals were used to modify commercial V2O5-WO3-TiO2 catalysts to remove slip ammonia and residual NOx from the tail of SCR system. The performance of selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 (NH3-SCO) and selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3 (NH3-SCR) of different catalysts at 150-400 ℃ was studied. The results showed that the loading of transition metals could significantly improve the NH3 oxidation ability of the catalysts, and the presence of NO furtherly promoted it. Cu-SCR catalyst obtained the best activity of both NH3 oxidation and NOx reduction at 350 ℃, and had excellent SO2 and H2O resistance in the presence of NO. The characterization results indicated that the transition metals enhanced the amounts of acid sites and redox ability of the catalysts. Moreover, the transition metals could increase the active oxygen and improve the catalytic performance of the catalysts by the redox reaction with V4+/V5+.
coredata.dc:title: Transition metals modified commercial SCR catalysts as efficient catalysts in NH3-SCO and NH3-SCR reactions
